explanation: To check the MISRA rule (memcmp shall not be used to compare null-terminated strings) you must inspect not only OS_DirectoryRewind itself but the called functions and relevant types/constants to see whether any path performs a memcmp on C strings. • OS_ObjectIdGetById, OS_DirRewind_Impl — direct callees; their bodies may invoke memcmp or forward string data to other functions. • OS_ObjectIdTransactionInit, OS_ObjectIdToArrayIndex, OS_ObjectIdConvertToken, OS_ObjectIdTransactionCancel, OS_ObjectIndexFromToken — functions called by the direct callees; memcmp usage may occur in deeper callees, so their implementations are required. • OS_object_token_t, osal_id_t — type definitions for tokens/IDs passed through these calls; needed to determine whether data passed to memcmp (if present) are pointers to null‑terminated strings or binary buffers. • LOCAL_OBJID_TYPE, OS_LOCK_MODE_NONE, OS_SUCCESS — macros/constants used as arguments/return values; required to understand control flow and which code paths execute (e.g., whether a branch that calls memcmp is reachable). • memcmp — the standard library symbol itself must be checked (where it appears) and its argument usage inspected to determine whether it is being applied to null‑terminated strings (which would violate the rule).
